LOAN SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Republic of Kazakhstan 
   
The Proposal  The proposed Kazakhstan Countercyclical Support Loan (KCSL) of 
$500,000,000,  utilizing  resources  from  the  Countercyclical  Support 
Facility  (CSF)  recently  approved  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank 
(ADB), will partly finance the anti-crisis plan (ACP) and employment-
generation  program  of  the  Government  of  Kazakhstan  (the 
Government).  It  will  be  disbursed  in  a  single  tranche  upon  loan 
effectiveness. 
   
Classification  Targeting Classification: General intervention 
Sector (subsectors): Public sector management (economic 
management and management of public affairs, social protection) 
Themes (subtheme): Economic growth (promoting macroeconomic 
stability) 
Location (impact): National (high impact)  
   
Environment  Category C 
Assessment 
   
The Program  Kazakhstan  was  the  first  country  in  the  Asia  Pacific  region  to  be 
Rationale  directly affected by the global economic crisis. After a decade of rapid 
expansion at 9% real gross domestic product (GDP) growth per year, 
the economy plummeted in the second half of 2008, limiting growth to 
3.3% that year. During January–June 2009, the economy is estimated 
to have contracted by 2.3% year-on-year, and the full-year decline in 
2009 is projected at 2%, according to the International Monetary Fund 
forecast. The financial sector was the worst affected, as banks were 
overexposed to external financing sources that dried up in August 
2007  as  the  international  liquidity  crisis  struck.  Global  creditors 
tightened liquidity, and Kazakh debt spreads widened sharply. Asset 
quality in the banking sector declined. The construction, industry, and 
trade sectors took major hits, with the impact of the crisis percolating 
down through the entire economy. There have been major job losses 
in some of these sectors. The impact of the crisis has also had ripple 
effects on the neighboring economies of the Kyrgyz Republic and the 
Republic  of  Tajikistan,  which  are  dependent  on  Kazakhstan  for 
investments as well as worker remittances. 
 
The  Government's  policy  response  and  actions  have  been  swift. 
Kazakhstan's ability to weather the crisis has been due in large part to 
a considerable chest of oil earnings built up in the National Fund of the 
Republic of Kazakhstan (NFRK), helped by the increase in oil prices 
until 2008. NFRK grew from $14 billion in 2006 to $28 billion in 2008. 
In 2007–2008, the Government set aside $4 billion equivalent in its 
budget to finance the ambitious ACP, formulated in late 2007 jointly 
with the National Bank of Kazakhstan (NBK), the Financial Monitoring 
Supervisory  Agency  (FMSA),  and  other  institutions.  In  November 
2008, the Government expanded its crisis-mitigation measures with an

ii 
 
additional  $10  billion  allocation  out  of  NFRK.  The  ACP  supports 
(i) banking sector rehabilitation, (ii) revival of the construction industry, 
(iii) greater role for small and medium-sized enterprises, (iv) revival of 
the agro-industrial sector, and (v) greater public investment in industry 
and  infrastructure.  It  took  a  75%  stake  in  Bank  Turan  Alem,  the 
country’s largest bank with 27% of the system's assets. It also injected 
capital  into  Halyk  Bank  and  Kazkommertzbank.  In  total,  the 
Government has put into the banking system equity capital or deposits 
amounting to $5 billion. Reacting to competitive pressures, Kazakhstan 
devalued the national currency, the tenge, by 20% in February 2009. 
An employment-generation program (Roadmap for Recovery Through 
Job Creation) was launched in March 2009. In total, the Government's 
anti-crisis package has mobilized $22.5 billion of direct and indirect 
measures, and is beginning to show results. 
 
There is multi-pronged rationale behind the KCSL: 
  
(i)  The  continued  slowdown  in  the  economy  over  the  past  18 
months,  its  direct  impact  on  the  financial  sector,  and  the 
second-round  effects  on  real  economic  activity  have 
accompanied  and  been  aggravated  by  severely  constrained 
access to international capital markets. While Kazakhstan has 
accumulated considerable resources in the National Fund of 
the Republic of Kazakhstan (NFRK), the national oil fund, the 
Government  has  already  explicitly  committed  $10  billion 
equivalent for crisis mitigation for 2009 alone. There are market 
expectations  that  the  NFRK  would  ring-fence  the  financial 
sector against panics. Hence, the Government would need to 
avoid further encumbering the liquidity of the NFRK by limiting 
the use of oil-sourced financial assets and revenues for short-
term purposes and diversifying its sources of financing.  
 
(ii) The  economic  slowdown  has  directly  imposed  higher  fiscal 
needs through lower tax revenues and higher social outlays. 
With discretionary expenditure and revenue measures taken in 
mid-2009, the budget deficit for 2009 is now forecast at 3.4%. 
To accommodate the estimated budget deficit of 3.4% of GDP, 
certain public expenditures were compressed to allow for fiscal 
resources reallocation to rising safety net needs. The KCSL will 
help  the  Government  shoulder  some  anti-crisis  expenditure 
requirements and thereby finance a part of the budget deficit. 
Without such assistance, there may be a corresponding cut in 
critical  expenditures  in  2009,  or  a  risky  attempt  at  tapping 
international  debt  markets,  which  now  price  Kazakhstan's 
sovereign debt abnormally high.  
 
(iii) Kazakhstan needs to rebuild its profile quickly when it begins to 
access  international  markets  again.  Engagement  with  an 
international financial institution could help in this regard. At a 
strategic level, the external shocks imposed by global turmoil 
have raised questions as to the country's ability to maintain its

iii 
past growth record. The Government recognizes the challenge 
and has begun to focus on economic diversification. 
 
(iv) Kazakhstan is a major economy in Central Asia and a delay in 
its recovery will have effects, in terms of trade and employment 
of  migrant  workers,  on  neighboring  countries'  economic 
prospects.  As  such,  supporting  Kazakhstan's  recovery  will 
likely have indirect benefits on other countries. 
 
Impact, Outcome,  The intended impact of the KCSL is to help Kazakhstan mitigate the 
and Outputs  impact of the global economic crisis. Its outcome will be greater fiscal 
stimulus. The principal output will be full-fledged implementation of the 
ACP  and  employment-generation  program,  which  will  support  key 
sectors of the economy and generate additional jobs. 
Scope and Coverage  The  KCSL  supports  the  Government's  countercyclical  expenditure 
of Loan  program  for  2009.  It  will  enable  the  Government  to  adopt  an 
expansionary fiscal stance. As resources from the KCSL will be co-
mingled  with  the  Government's  own  resources,  all  areas  of  the 
Government's countercyclical program will be included in KCSL scope.  
Financing Plan  The Government has requested a loan of $500,000,000 under the CSF 
from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, with interest to be determined 
in  accordance  with  ADB's  London  interbank-offered  rate  (LIBOR)–
based lending facility plus 200 basis points; a 5-year term, including a 
grace period of 3 years; a commitment charge of 75 basis points on 
undisbursed loan balances, and such other terms and conditions as 
are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft Loan 
Agreement.  
 
Period and  The KCSL will support budgetary financing requirements related to 
Tranching  ACP and the employment generation program in the current fiscal 
year, i.e. ending 31 December 2009 and is expected to be fully utilized 
by June 2010. The $500 million loan will be disbursed in a single 
tranche upon loan effectiveness. 
   
Counterpart Funds  The  Government  will  use  the  local  currency  counterpart  funds 
generated by the loan proceeds to help maintain critical countercyclical 
expenditures, such as for job creation and restoring economic stability. 
   
Executing Agency   Ministry of Finance 
   
Implementation  and  The  Government's  implementation  arrangements  for  the  ACP  and 
Monitoring  employment-generation program will be extended to the KCSL. The 
Arrangements  Ministry of Economy and Budget Planning deals with the strategic 
aspects  of  the  ACP,  with  NBK,  FMSA,  and  selected  economic 
ministries  providing  sector  content  and  oversight.  Overall  program 
execution  under  the  ACP  is  overseen  by  Samruk-Kazyna,  the 
sovereign wealth fund. The Ministry of Labor and Social Protection 
coordinates the employment-generation program.

iv 
 
Given the severity of the crisis and the extent of resources allocated 
for  crisis-mitigation,  the  Government  has  put  in  place  elaborate 
monitoring  and  reporting  arrangements,  with  weekly  assessments 
presented to the senior leadership of the country.  
   
Procurement and  The loan proceeds will be used to finance the full foreign exchange 
Disbursement  costs  (excluding  local  duties  and  taxes)  of  items  produced  and 
procured  in  ADB  member  countries,  excluding  ineligible  items  and 
imports financed by other bilateral and multilateral sources. The loan 
proceeds will be disbursed to the Borrower in accordance with the 
provisions of ADB’s Simplification of Disbursement Procedures and 
Related Requirements for Program Loans. 
   
Benefits and  The KCSL will have a substantially beneficial impact on Kazakhstan's 
Beneficiaries  economy by 
(i)  partly meeting the resource needs of the ACP, which has 
become  synonymous  with  crisis  mitigation  in 
Kazakhstan;  
(ii)  creating  jobs  by  reviving  construction,  small  and 
medium-sized enterprises, and agro industries, as well 
as through dedicated public works programs;  
(iv)  indirectly  supporting  restoration  of  banking  sector 
stability; and 
(v)  reducing  reliance  on  NFRK  and  diversifying  funding 
sources. 
 
Risks and  Kazakhstan has withstood crisis shocks thus far quite effectively. The 
Assumptions  significant pool of oil resources and prudent fiscal management of 
recent years have helped. While the economy is forecast to recover in 
2010 with favorable medium-term growth prospects, there are several 
risks that Kazakhstan faces, including the following: 
  
(i)  Slow  regional  and  global  recovery  and  uncertain 
commodity  prices.  Kazakhstan's  economy  depends 
heavily on developments in the West, as well as within its 
neighbors,  particularly  the  Russian  Federation.  Its 
metallurgical  sector  has  been  adversely  affected  by 
slowing  demand  in  the  region  for  iron  ore  and  other 
metals. Kazakhstan's pace of recovery is also predicated 
on oil prices and how long they will stay above $65–$70 
per barrel.  
(ii)  Economic slowdown-induced banking distress. The 
banking  sector  has  been  slow  to  recover,  with 
nonperforming  loans  continuing  to  increase.  Tardy 
economic  recovery  will  slow  progress  in  bringing  the 
banking  sector  back  to  a  sound  footing,  which  will 
continue to be affected by inadequate funding sources. 
NBK  and  FMSA  have  tightened  their  policy  and 
oversight, but sector restructuring needs to be closely 
monitored.

v 
 
(iii)  Banking  distress-induced  disruption  to  economic 
activity. In the current circumstances of heightened risk 
aversion and liquidity problems, the financial sector can 
recover only slowly, limiting its ability to assist aggregate 
demand recovery and expansion. In the meantime, any 
further  deterioration  of  solvency  indicators  and 
depositors' confidence would add a new dimension of 
disruption  to  economic  activity.  This  risk  has  been 
recognized and acted upon by the authorities with swift 
confidence-building measures. 
  (iv)  Inability  to  mobilize  domestic  resources.  Clearly, 
Kazakhstan cannot rely on external borrowing at levels 
close to 100% of GDP, as it does now. It is imperative 
that  the  country  come  up  with  sustainable  domestic 
financial intermediation alternatives. This is a tall order 
but one that needs to be filled. 
(v)  Governance  concerns.  Mobilizing  capital  on  a 
sustained basis will require greater transparency and a 
better  investment  climate.  There  are  concerns  that 
investors'  rights  may  not  always  be  protected  in  the 
country. In times like these when global markets price 
marginal risks with great variance, Kazakhstan needs to 
attract greater investments, including investment outside 
the  oil  sector.  Recognizing  the  problems,  the 
Government has taken a few important measures. It has 
adopted a comprehensive anticorruption program. It has 
also expressed its commitment to the Extractive Industry 
Transparency Initiative. The medium-term reforms under 
the ACP are expected to help in attracting investments.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to Kazakhstan for countercyclical support. The status of the country's compliance with the 
access criteria for the Countercyclical Support Facility (CSF) is in Appendix 1. A development 
policy letter confirming the countercyclical spending program of the Government of Kazakhstan 
(the Government) and its medium-term development program is in Appendix 2. 
 
II.  THE REQUEST FOR THE COUNTERCYCLICAL SUPPORT LOAN 
2.  Kazakhstan's economy grew at an average rate of over 9% per year for several years 
prior to 2008. Backed by a strong growth in oil revenues, it undertook significant structural 
reforms during the past decade. The incidence of poverty declined from close to 40% in the late 
1990s to 20% in 2004 and further to an estimated 14% in 2008. Sustained growth created jobs 
and almost quadrupled per capita income over a 10-year span from 1997 to about $7,500. The 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been engaged with the Government since Kazakhstan 
became a member in 1994. ADB's strategy focuses largely on infrastructure development. 
Towards policy reforms, it has thus far provided only one policy-based loan, in 1996 for the 
Pension  Reform  Program.  ADB's  private  sector  operations  picked  up  pace  in  2006,  with 
cumulative debt transactions totaling $244 million with four banks. 
 
3.  Rationale for the Proposed Loan. As summarized in the staff assessment of CSF 
access criteria (Section III–IV below and Appendix 1), the exogenous shocks caused by the 
global financial turmoil and subsequent economic slowdown have left Kazakhstan in difficult 
economic  circumstances,  with  the  financial  and  some  other  key  sectors  of  the  economy 
adversely  affected.  The  Government  has  taken  swift  and  commendable  actions,  including 
formulating an ambitious anti-crisis plan (ACP). It has asked ADB for a $500 million loan from 
the  CSF:  the  Kazakhstan  Countercyclical  Support  Loan  (KCSL).  There  is  multi-pronged 
rationale behind the KCSL:1 
 
(i)  The continued slowdown in the economy over the past 18 months, its direct impact on 
the  financial  sector,  and  the  second-round  effects  on  real  economic  activity  have 
accompanied  and  been  aggravated  by  severely  constrained  access  to  international 
capital  markets.  While  Kazakhstan  has  accumulated  considerable  resources  in  the 
National  Fund  of  the  Republic  of  Kazakhstan  (NFRK),  the  national  oil  fund,  the 
Government has already explicitly committed $10 billion equivalent for crisis mitigation 
for 2009 alone. There are market expectations that the NFRK would ring-fence the 
financial sector against panics. Hence, the Government would need to avoid further 
encumbering the liquidity of the NFRK by limiting the use of oil-sourced financial assets 
and revenues for short-term purposes and diversifying its sources of financing.  
 
(ii) The economic slowdown has directly imposed higher fiscal needs through lower tax 
revenues  and  higher  social  outlays.  With  discretionary  expenditure  and  revenue 
measures taken in mid-2009, the budget deficit for 2009 is now forecast at 3.4%. To 
accommodate the estimated budget deficit of 3.4% of GDP, certain public expenditures 
were compressed to allow for fiscal resources reallocation to rising safety net needs. 
The KCSL will help the Government shoulder some anti-crisis expenditure requirements 
and thereby finance a part of the budget deficit. Without such assistance, there may be a 
corresponding  cut  in  critical  expenditures  in  2009,  or  a  risky  attempt  at  tapping

III.  IMPACT OF THE GLOBAL CRISIS2  
A.  Economic Impact 
4.  Economic Crisis and Growth Outlook. The Kazakh economy has been struck by two 
rounds of exogenous shocks. The international liquidity crunch first (the first-round shock) and 
the slowdown in global demand for commodities thereafter (the second-round shock) brought 
down growth to 3.3% in 2008, against the 9% average during 2000–2007. Figure 1 presents the 
dynamics of these two rounds of shocks. In 2009, the economy is expected to contract by as 
much as 2% (Figure 2) as per projections by the International Monetary Fund (IMF), due to 
declining export revenues, itself a reflection of depressed international commodity prices, and a 
contraction in private domestic expenditures. 
 
5.  First-Round Shocks to the Financial Sector. Over 2004–2007, Kazakh banks' lending 
had grown increasingly reliant on international credit markets through the issuance of short-term 
debt and cheap access to international refinancing and rolling-over options. A few big banks in 
Kazakhstan also channeled these resources to banking subsidiaries in other Central Asian 
countries  and  the  Russian  Federation.  Between  2006  and  2008,  banking sector  assets  in 
Kazakhstan grew by close to 200%. In parallel, high lending growth with increasing exposure to 
real estate (property development projects and individual mortgages) kept pushing property 
prices up. The upward spiraling of asset prices, however, became increasingly disconnected 
from market fundamentals and was propelled mostly by the constant growth of bank lending, 
which fueled speculative property demand.3

6.  The onset of global turmoil in August 2007 brought about a sudden reversal in capital 
inflows. International liquidity for Kazakhstan and other emerging markets started to freeze, and

consumption of durables. In late 2007, the self-reinforcing dynamic in property prices discussed 
above burst, triggered by the sudden standstill in bank lending. Property prices nose-dived in 
many  cases  to  less  than  half  of  the  peak  (Figure  5),  and  revealed  demand  for  property

8.  Against this backdrop, the Government implemented from 2007 onwards a number of (i) 
anti-crisis measures aiming to unlock the capacity of financial intermediation in Kazakhstan to 
provide credit to key sectors of the economy, and (ii) countercyclical measures of scaling up 
public investments to support aggregate expenditure and employment generation. However, 
bank lending remains stagnant. The nominal growth in the first half of 2009 of 12% year-on-year 
in banks' outstanding credit is mostly a reflection of the 20% depreciation of the Kazakh tenge in 
February 2009.  
 
9.  Second-Round  Shocks  to  External  Demand.  A  combination  of  factors  strongly 
affected growth in external demand for Kazakhstan's output in the last quarter of 2008 and first 
6 months of 2009. In contrast with the nominal export expansion that occurred in 2008, which in 
a direct way had mitigated the negative effects on economic growth of the 2007 sudden stop in 
capital inflows, the collapse in international commodity prices brought down the total export 
turnover of Kazakhstan by 51% when compared with the same period in 2008 (i.e., year-on-
year), despite an increase in the volume of exports in the first half of 2009.4 This was a 
significant demand shock to the economy, resulting partly from the economic slowdown in the 
Russian Federation, a large importer of energy and metallurgical products from Kazakhstan. As 
a consequence, industrial activity declined by 5% year-on-year during January–June 2009.

represents on average more than 40% of GDP in Kazakhstan. In the first half of 2009, total 
household consumption decreased by 2.2% against the same period in 2008 in real terms.5 
Investment expenditure (total capital formation) was also hit hard in the first quarter of 2009, 
having fallen by 4.9% vis-à-vis the first quarter of 2008. Investment recovered in the second 
quarter of 2009, so that year-on-year real growth in the first half of 2009 reached 7.3%. This 
reflected a combination of public and private investment, with both increasing markedly as a

12.  Exchange Rate and Monetary Policy Management. The Kazakh tenge was pegged to 
the US dollar in late 2007. While this policy was maintained during 2008, speculative pressures 
on the currency mounted as commodity prices declined in late 2008 and the Russian ruble 
steadily  depreciated.  Intense  capital  flight  and  increasing  dollarization  was  an  immediate 
phenomena at the end of 2008. Foreign currency deposits of individuals almost doubled from 
January 2008 to February 2009. The National Bank of Kazakhstan (NBK) intervened in defense 
of the exchange-rate peg until mid-February 2009, resulting in a decline in foreign exchange 
reserves  by  17%  between  September  2008  and  January  2009.  External  macroeconomic 
balance conditions were reassessed by the NBK in February 2009, and the tenge was devalued 
by 20% to T150 to the dollar, and the new dollar exchange-rate peg (under a 3% band) is to be 
maintained until the global economy stabilizes.  
 
13.  The new exchange rate is assessed to be in line with market fundamentals. A more 
competitive  exchange  rate  is  showing  results.  Over  June–July  2009,  the  contraction  in 
aggregate demand was less steep, with several indicators of economic activity showing signs of 
stabilization, especially in mining and manufacturing. Nonetheless, and in terms of the volume 
of industrial production, the first 6 months of 2009 showed a contraction of 2.7% relative to the 
same period in 2008, reflecting a 9.5% contraction in manufacturing, mostly in metallurgic 
production. The construction sector, an engine of constant and strong growth in the past few 
years, contracted by 8.3% in the first half of 2009 vis-à-vis the first half of 2008. Kazakh 
monetary and financial authorities have had to strike a difficult balance to restore stability in a 
highly dollarized financial system. Their actions have been supported by accumulated external 
reserves, which have increased from $17.6 billion at the end of 2007 to $19.9 billion at present 
(the equivalent of slightly less than 7 months of imports), notwithstanding the need to maintain 
the peg.  
 
14.  Financial Sector Stability, and Regulatory Actions. These resources have helped 
Kazakhstan deal with stress in the banking sector, which had accumulated between 2005 and 
2007 a significant open foreign exchange position, exposing it to currency depreciation. This is 
now recognized as an important source of macroeconomic vulnerability. The erosion in capital 
adequacy in a few banks triggered by the 20% currency devaluation was taken into account, 
and  equity  reinforcements  were  required  by  the  Financial  Monitoring  Supervisory  Agency 
(FMSA). As discussed in Section IV on Kazakhstan's anti-crisis measures, the Government has 
acquired equity stakes in three top banks: Bank Turan Alem (75%), Halyk Bank (21%), and 
Kazkommertzbank (20%). NBK has strengthened the capital base of the Kazakhstan Deposit 
Insurance Fund fourfold to T100 billion ($670 million). Its coverage per depositor per bank has 
been increased from T0.7 million ($4,666) to T5 million ($33,333). At present, Kazakhstan 
Deposit Insurance Fund reserves are considered adequate to meet short-term contingencies.

7
Further, it has the right to borrow from NBK. In line with the 2008 Financial Sector Assessment 
Program  recommendations  made  by  a  joint  mission  of  the  IMF  and  the  World  Bank,  the 
authorities have adopted a comprehensive contingency plan to deal with systemic problems in 
the banking sector. This plan has been effectively used to deal with the current crisis. 
 
15.  Banks are cautious about lending tenge due to uncertainty regarding the near-term 
evolution of the exchange rate, especially if the Russian ruble continues to slide and the 
recovery in oil prices is not sustained. At the same time, heightened awareness of currency-
induced credit risk acts as a disincentive to dollar lending. As a result, financial intermediation is 
severely  constrained.  Recognition  of  other  current  sources  of  vulnerability  in  the  financial 
system, such as the risk of loss of confidence, is behind commercial banks' recent liquidity 
hoarding, causing a hike in excess reserves. Although NBK and FMSA reduced the ratio of 
required reserves to 2.5% for tenge and 1.5% for US dollar deposits in the midst of liquidity 
problems in two large banks, the total amount of reserves in the banking system has actually 
increased. NBK attempted to relieve credit constraints by lowering the interbank rate from 
10.5% in December 2008 to 7.5% in July 2009. This move currently appears to support banks in 
the process of restructuring, while the remaining banks have yet to avail themselves of the NBK 
lending window. Continued close coordination is vital between monetary and exchange rate 
policies and financial sector oversight. 
 
16.  NBK has set a positive precedent in previous episodes of banking difficulties by honoring 
its commitment to treat banks firmly but fairly.6 FMSA has increased its monitoring and oversight. 
It examines bank financials monthly, conducts modified stress tests regularly, and is preparing 
new prudential guidelines that are expected to be in force once the current round of international 
creditor  negotiations  is  completed.  FMSA's  undivided  attention  is  now  on  the  systemically 
important banks that need significant asset restructuring and creditor workouts, as related 
Government programs take shape. 
 
17.  Fiscal Impact. Kazakhstan's fiscal management became stronger as the economy grew 
over the past decade. NFRK, established in August 2000, has consolidated all revenues from 
the extractive sector and has been used prudently, generally to meet social safety net needs or 
provide funding to national development institutions. The severity of the crisis has necessitated 
large transfers and commitments from NFRK.  
 
18.  As for 2009, revenue compression is inevitable (Table 1). Estimates of tax revenues in 
the Republican Budget (which consists of non-oil tax revenues) for 2009 have already been 
reduced by 12% compared with 2008, as the tax code provided tax easing as a crisis response. 
However, non-oil tax revenue was further cut by another 20% during the April 2009 budget 
revisions, as the economy contracted in the first quarter, reflecting weak business activity and 
consumer demand. Tax and non-tax revenues from oil enterprises, which accrue directly into 
NFRK, have also declined. January–August 2009 oil revenues declined by 28% compared with 
the same period in 2008, from T955 billion to T683 billion.7

23.  Unemployment. As discussed above, the economic sectors that suffered most from the 
contraction in the first half of 2009 were such labor-intensive ones as construction services, 
metallurgy, and mining. Together these sectors account for a significant share of the economy 
and employ close to 25% of the active labor force (comprising 65% men and 35% women). The 
official unemployment rate was around 6.5% at the end of the second half of 2008, it went up to 
7.2% by April 2009, and has since come down to 6.7% as measured at the end of June 2009, 
which  may  also  reflect  the  launching  of  the  Government's  direct  employment-generation 
program. However, it is likely that there may be a lag for the full-scale impact of the crisis to filter 
through into layoffs. At the same time, there are clear signs of vulnerability. For instance, the 
number of applicants seeking unemployment insurance benefits has increased sharply, from 
567 claimants in 2007 to 1,712 in 2008 and to 8,882 in the first half of 2009. 
 
24.  Gender. The economic crisis has affected people generally in Kazakhstan. An analysis 
of the distribution of employment by gender across economic activities indicates that there are 
fewer women than men employed in the sectors that were hit hardest by the crisis (Table A7 in 
Appendix 6). For example, among the hardest hit economic activities are manufacturing (-11.5% 
growth  in  January–May  2009),  construction  (-8.3%);  transport  and  communication  (-7.9%); 
power distribution and water supply (-7.6%); and trade (-6.8%). Except for trade, all have a 
higher share of men employed, ranging from 63% to 75%. Although the worst-affected sectors 
predominantly  employ  male  workers,  studies  from  the  1997  Asian  financial  crisis  highlight 
situations where women may be discriminated against in layoff decisions.  
 
25.  There is no evidence yet of any disproportionate effects on women when compared with 
men. However, there may be some time lag before the emergence of a clear indication of crisis 
impact on women. The gender gap in wages is around 40% and men are also said to have 
benefited  more  from  economic  progress  in  previous  years.12 Therefore,  given  women’s 
vulnerability  to  poverty,  any  increases  in  unemployment  among  women  could  have  a 
disproportionate impact on women’s poverty levels.

A.  Economic Stimulus and Social Safety Nets 
 
30.  Reviving the Construction Sector and Real Estate Markets. Kazakhstan's anti-crisis 
measures seek to ease the liquidity constraints faced in housing construction and real estate 
sectors in different ways. Most of the initiatives do not involve direct transfers to locally-identified 
beneficiaries, but rather support (through financing of banks) firms' refinancing (pre-termination 
of existing loans and restructuring loan terms) of existing bank loans. In this way, credit risk in 
existing loan books got reduced, which supports both banks and borrowers. As a result, many 
housing projects were completed at a cheaper financing cost, through both banks and the Real 
Estate Fund. This aimed to prevent job losses that would have occurred had construction been 
discontinued.  
31.  Also, with the ACP for 2007–2008, the Government provided refinancing to developers 
through  bank  funds  and  directly  acquired  uncompleted  housing  construction  projects.  This 
resulted in the completion of 22,140 apartments in Astana and Almaty by end-June 2009. The 
expansion  of  the  mortgage  refinancing  under  the  ACP  for  2009-2010  further  allows  the 
completion of construction projects. As of June 2009, a total of 24,566 mortgage borrowers 
have  benefited  from  the  refinancing  scheme,  and  would  expect  the  completion  of  their 
apartments.  
 
32.  SME  Support.  Anti-crisis  measures  to  help  SMEs  included  the  same  refinancing 
schemes largely in line with those described above for construction and real estate, as a means 
of maintaining their ongoing projects as well as spurring new activity. The 2007–2008 crisis 
measures have benefited 5,818 SMEs. This supported a total of 8,997 jobs. The ACP for 2009–

2010 provided additional financial support, of which 70% is being used for refinancing of existing 
projects, and the remaining portion for the implementation of new projects. The funds will be 
channeled through 12 banks and the Damu Fund, set up to spur entrepreneurial development. 
By 3 July 2009, the banks had entered into contracts for 2,551 SME projects amounting to 
T133.6 billion,19 and have released funds to 2,376 SME projects. The Government reports that 
the number of active SMEs in the first 5 months of 2009 has increased by 9.5%. 
 
33.  Agro-Industrial  Sector  Support. The Government has identified the agro-industrial 
sector as a key area for stabilizing the economy, as it accounts for 30% of employment. It is 
also key to ensuring food security. Measures in the 2007–2008 package included lending to 
agro-industrial companies and grain procurement for food security. Under the ACP for 2009–
2010, the Government is to finance agro-industrial projects through KazAgro. The number of 
applications received has reached 156, amounting to T178.8 billion. Of these, 20 projects worth 
T25.4 billion have been approved. 
 
34.  Support for Innovative, Industrial, and Infrastructure Projects. Under the ACP for 
2009–2010,  the  Government  will  support  the  implementation  of  innovative,  industrial,  and 
infrastructure projects to generate employment. It has considered 26 projects in the energy, 
transport infrastructure, oil and gas, and manufacturing sectors amounting to $19.5 million, for 
which $3.5 million in state support is being solicited. 
 
35.  Employment Generation. The employment-generation program was approved in March 
2009 to provide direct fiscal stimulus and address the effects of the crisis on employment. The 
program,  involving  eight  ministries  and  coordinated  by  the  Ministry  of  Labor  and  Social 
Protection (MLSP), is targeted to generate employment through seven key interventions. The 
first four measures invest in the repair and reconstruction of (i) local urban facilities; (ii) roads; 
(iii) schools,  hospitals,  and  other  social  institutions;  and  (iv)  facilities  in  rural  areas.  The 
remaining three components focus on (i) retraining programs, (ii) creation of social jobs20, and 
(iii) internships. The program aims to create 350,000 jobs. To allow its quick implementation, the 
Public Procurement Law was revised to allow the program's use of special procedures to reduce 
the procurement period. In addition to the employment measures, to improve social protection, 
the period of eligibility for the unemployment allowance was increased from 4 to 6 months.

program. The investment component, expected to generate 254,232 jobs, created 252,277 jobs 
in 4,773 projects. Of these, 211,039 have been filled. Local governments have provided 77,000 
additional new jobs. The retraining program benefited 44,675 people. An additional 51,089 
people have been provided with social jobs, 83% of the target of 61,248 people. The internship 
component has achieved 98% of its target of 34,452 people.

B.  Financial Sector Stabilization 
 
38.  Capital  and  Deposit  Infusion.  Under  the  ACP,  T488  billion  ($4  billion)  has  been 
allocated  to  stabilize  the  financial  sector  and  improve  confidence  in  the  banking  system. 
Samruk-Kazyna  infused  equity  and  deposits  in  four  major  banks  to  improve  financial 
intermediation. There has been significant progress in providing liquidity support to the banking 
sector. As of end-June 2009, this has brought a capital infusion of T212.7 billion in Bank Turan 
Alem  (BTA),  T60  billion  in  Halyk  Bank,  and  T36  billion  in  Kazkommertzbank.  In  addition, 
Government deposits of T60 billion have been channeled into Halyk Bank, T24 billion in Alliance

constraints, there is a need to adopt comprehensive measures to restore confidence in the 
banking sector. This would include resolving the debts of the distressed banks, which are at 
present finalizing restructuring agreements with their creditors.  
 
39.  Exit Strategy. The Government has indicated that it does not intend to remain a long-
term investor in private commercial banks. It plans to sell its current ownership of banks' equity 
as soon as the economy starts to recover and banks' access to international capital markets is 
restored. Banks' private shareholders will be allowed to buy the Government's shares within 5 
years. 
 
40.  Mortgage and SME refinancing. As part of the measures to improve the balance sheet 
of banks, Samruk-Kazyna infused deposits to the banks to allow the refinancing of mortgages 
and SME projects. The ACP for 2009–2010 expanded support to the real estate sector by 
providing  mortgage  refinancing.  Samruk-Kazyna  allocated  T240  billion  to  support  the 
construction  sector.  Of  this,  (i)  T15  billion  was  used  to capitalize  the  real  estate  fund  for 
purchasing and completing residential and other projects for future leasing; (ii) T17.1 billion has 
been transferred to commercial banks to finance the completion of construction projects, of 
which  T4.2  billion  has  been  received  by  borrowers;  and  (iii)  T25.3  billion  was  to  provide 
provisional financing to developers to resume construction projects. Ten banks were allocated 
T120 billion, and by end-June 2009 mortgages amounting to T95.5 billion have been refinanced 
at lower interest rates. 
 
41.  Samruk-Kazyna has channeled T117 billion through 12 banks for either refinancing or 
new lending to SMEs. As of June 2009, with some banks contributing from own funds for this 
initiative, banks and SMEs have entered into contracts worth T133.6 billion. T107 billion have 
been released to the SMEs. 
 
42.  Liquidity  Adjustment. Several shocks to confidence in the banking sector brought 
liquidity in the financial sector below regulatory minimums. Together with deposit mobilization 
undertaken  through  state-owned  enterprises  to  increase  liquidity  in  banks  and  shore  up 
depositors' confidence, the authorities reduced reserve requirements in November 2008 in an 
effort to stimulate bank lending. However, total reserves in the banking system have increased, 
reflecting natural liquidity hoarding and no growth in loan demand. 
 
43.  Distressed  Asset  Fund.  The  Distressed  Asset  Fund  was  established  in  2008  to

the Government are committed to working closely together to determine how to use the fund in 
line with the financial sector component of the ACP.

C.  Reforms under the ACP  
 
44.  In addition to the immediate measures to mitigate the impact of the global crisis, the 
ACP includes legal and regulatory reforms to improve the business climate. These reforms are

V.  THE PROPOSED COUNTERCYCLICAL SUPPORT LOAN 
 
49.  Impact,  Outcome,  and  Outputs.  The  intended  impact  of  the  KCSL  is  to  help 
Kazakhstan mitigate the impact of the global economic crisis. Its outcome will be greater fiscal 
stimulus.  The  principal  output  will  be  the  full-fledged  implementation  of  the  ACP  and 
employment-generation program, which will support key sectors of the economy and result in 
additional jobs. The Government will use proceeds from the KCSL largely to meet ACP and 
employment-generation program requirements. As the proceeds will flow through the budget, 
the Government will co-mingle KCSL local currency proceeds with its own resources. 
 
50.  Government's  Financing  Requirements  and  Scope  of  the  KCSL.  Not  including 
NFRK inflows, Kazakhstan's fiscal position has become quite vulnerable in 2009, given the 
severity of the crisis. As noted earlier (Table 1), the revised 2009 Republican Budget projects a 
revenue decline of almost 30%, or T623 billion ($4.1 billion), against 2008. The budget revision 
resulted in significant expenditure reallocation among sectors, with low-priority expenditures 
being reduced (Table 2). The Government increased expenditures on social security, social 
assistance, housing, and communal facilities by 22%, while cutting the allocation for almost all 
the other sectors. This also included deferral of the construction of new education and health 
facilities which were not deemed as immediate. Instead, resources have been directed for either 
safety nets or "shovel-ready" public works projects. As a result of the budgetary realignment, the 
overall deficit, excluding targeted NFRK transfers, is estimated at T922 billion, or $6.1 billion. 
About a third of this gap will be met by targeted transfers from NFRK, leaving an unfunded 
deficit of T574 billion ($3.8 billion), translating to 3.4% of GDP. The critical unmet needs include, 
among other things, social security and social aid (T135 billion or $894 million) and housing and 
communal facilities (T42 billion or $278 million).

VI.  FIDUCIARY DUE DILIGENCE AND IMPLEMENTATION ARRANGEMENTS 
A.  Public Debt Sustainability 
 
52.  Kazakhstan has consistently kept its public debt at low and manageable levels (Table 3). 
Between 2006 and 2008, public and publicly guaranteed debt was at an average of 6.4% of 
GDP.24 Taking into account the asset portfolio of the country's oil fund, which can be quickly 
mobilized to offset any debt shocks, the net public debt is negative, averaging –12.8% of GDP. 
This clearly indicates that public debt is more than adequately covered and does not pose a risk 
to the economy. Moreover, the foreign exchange risk associated with public debt is quite low, as 
80% of the public debt is domestic. The ratio of public external debt to GDP averaged 1.5% in 
2006–2008. For 2009, excluding the KCSL, the ratio of public debt to GDP is expected to 
increase to 8.6%, and the ratio of public external debt to GDP is projected at 1.5% of GDP.

B.  Public Financial Management System 
 
54.  As far as the ACP is concerned, the Government has established sound implementation, 
monitoring and internal control arrangements (Appendix 7, Figures A7.1 and A7.2). At a broader 
level  in  the  public  financial  management  area,  Kazakhstan  has  established  a  transparent 
system of budget preparation, execution, and reporting. Monthly budget execution reports are 
available in the MOF's website. Kazakhstan has adopted a multiyear budgeting framework, with 
its first medium-term budget operational from 2009 to 2011. Internal control systems are in 
place at two levels. Each line ministry has an internal audit wing. In addition, the Committee for 
Financial Control, under the Ministry of Finance, monitors and checks budget execution and 
disbursement. Monthly reports are provided by committee personnel. Scheduled inspections are 
conducted once every 2 years, and unscheduled inspections are conducted as needed. The 
committee releases quarterly reports on its activities and provides the President with reports on 
violations every semester. The committee is plans to implement risk-based inspections in 2010. 
It also monitors the disbursement of funds from government loans. The committee acts as the 
centralized procurement agency for ministries and agencies of the central Government. External 
audit is conducted by the accounts committee. 
 
55.  The Public Procurement Law was adopted in 2002 to develop a transparent, competitive, 
and objective public procurement regime. It requires competitive bidding for major procurements 
and provides strict formal requirements to limit the extent of single sourcing. Access to the 
procurement process is well advertised and open to companies and individuals. Amendments to 
the law in 2008 limited the powers of government agencies to influence the public procurement 
process. This aimed to improve transparency and openness, eliminate major possibilities for 
corruption  in  public  procurement,  and  introduce  an  electronic  procurement  system,  to  be 
implemented in 2010. 
 
C.  Anticorruption Framework 
 
56.  Kazakhstan has a well defined legal and institutional framework for combating corruption. 
The anti-corruption law (Law on Fight Against Corruption) was adopted in 1998. It defines the 
core principles underlying the anticorruption effort, types of corruption crimes, and responsible 
agencies.  Whistle-blowing  is  supported  and  protected  under  the  law.  The  criminal  code 
criminalizes  active  and  passive  bribery,  attempted  corruption,  extortion,  money  laundering, 
abuse  of  office,  and  bribe  facilitation  by  third  parties.  The  Law  on  Civil  Service  and  the

21
anticorruption law require public officials to report conflicts of interest, though a mechanism for 
addressing such conflicts of interest is required.  
 
57.  The Agency of the Republic of Kazakhstan on Fighting with Economic and Corruption 
Crimes (i.e., the financial police) is responsible for investigating 44 different types of economic 
crime,  such  as  active  and  passive  bribery,  abuse  of  authority,  and  smuggling.  In  2006, 
Kazakhstan adopted the State Program on Fighting Corruption for 2006–2010, and an action 
plan was adopted for its implementation. Among the key components are improving the legal 
framework, strengthening enforcement and judicial systems, promoting public awareness, and 
involving civil society in anticorruption activities. 
 
58.  While Kazakhstan's anticorruption legal and institutional framework is relatively broad 
and strong, there certainly is room for improvement. One improvement would be to make the 
legal  framework  more  preventive  than  curative.  There  is  also  scope  for  improving  the 
enforcement and implementation of the framework. 
 
59.  In terms of international anticorruption cooperation, Kazakhstan joined the ADB/OECD 
Anticorruption  Initiative  for  Asia-Pacific  in  May  2002.  It  acceded  to  the  United  Nations 
Convention Against Corruption in June 2008.

VII.  BENEFITS, RISKS, AND ASSUMPTIONS 
69.  Benefits. Kazakhstan has taken wide-ranging measures to mitigate the adverse impacts 
of global financial turmoil. It has allocated significant budgetary and NFRK resources. The 
proposed KCSL will benefit Kazakhstan by reinforcing the ACP and augmenting the fiscal 
stimulus that the country has mobilized using its own sources. It will help Kazakhstan reduce 
over-reliance on NFRK for short-term purposes and diversify its funding sources. The provision 
of  the  KCSL,  which  recognizes  the  anti-crisis  measures  as  effective,  will  also  help  raise 
Kazakhstan's profile as it approaches international capital markets once normalcy returns. By 
being an integral part of the ACP, loan proceeds will help in job creation by reviving the 
construction sector, SMEs and agro-industries, as well as through the dedicated public works 
programs. The proposed loan will also indirectly help restore banking system stability. 
 
70.  Kazakhstan has withstood crisis shocks thus far quite effectively. The significant pool of 
oil resources and prudent fiscal management of recent years have helped. While the economy 
is forecast to recover in 2010 with favorable medium-term growth prospects, there are several 
risks that Kazakhstan faces, including the following: 
  
(i)  Slow  regional  and  global  recovery  and  uncertain  commodity  prices. 
Kazakhstan's economy depends heavily on developments in the West, as well as 
within its neighbors, particularly the Russian Federation. Its metallurgical sector 
has been adversely affected by slowing demand in the region for iron ore and 
other metals. Kazakhstan's pace of recovery is also predicated on oil prices and 
how long they will stay above $65–$70 per barrel.  
(ii)  Economic slowdown-induced banking distress. The banking sector has been 
slow  to  recover,  with  nonperforming  loans  continuing  to  increase.  Tardy 
economic recovery will slow progress in bringing the banking sector back to a 
sound footing, which will continue to be affected by inadequate funding sources. 
NBK  and  FMSA  have  tightened  their  policy  and  oversight,  but  sector 
restructuring needs to be closely monitored.  
(iii)  Banking  distress-induced  disruption  to  economic  activity. In the current 
circumstances of heightened risk aversion and liquidity problems, the financial 
sector can recover only slowly, limiting its ability to assist aggregate demand 
recovery and expansion. In the meantime, any further deterioration of solvency 
indicators and depositors' confidence would add a new dimension of disruption to 
economic  activity.  This  risk  has  been  recognized  and  acted  upon  by  the 
authorities with swift confidence-building measures.

24     
(iv)  Inability to mobilize domestic resources. Clearly, Kazakhstan cannot rely on 
external  borrowing  at  levels  close  to  100%  of  GDP,  as  it  does  now.  It  is 
imperative  that  the  country  come  up  with  sustainable  domestic  financial 
intermediation alternatives. This is a tall order but one that needs to be filled. 
 
(v)  Governance  concerns.  Mobilizing  capital  on  a  sustained  basis  will  require 
greater transparency and a better investment climate. There are concerns that 
investors' rights may not always be protected in the country. In times like these 
when global markets price marginal risks with great variance, Kazakhstan needs 
to  attract  greater  investments,  including  investment  outside  the  oil  sector. 
Recognizing the problems, the Government has taken a few important measures. 
It has adopted a comprehensive anticorruption program. It has also expressed its 
commitment to the Extractive Industry Transparency Initiative. The medium-term 
reforms under the ACP (para.44) are expected to help in attracting investments.

B.  Banks, Borrowers, and Global Credit 
 
73.  In 2005, banks increasingly turned to the global financial markets to underwrite the 
growth in credit. About half of bank credit expansion in Kazakhstan was funded from abroad. 
These sources proved to be exceptionally easy to access over the years, as international 
investors reached for yields in ever-longer maturities, incentivized by a relatively flat yield curve 
and historically low interest rates.1 Since Kazkommertzbank issued its first eurobond in 1998, all 
leading  Kazakh  banks gained  access  to  international capital  markets  and,  in  the  process, 
became increasingly dependent on them. These global sources are quick to close off funds, 
especially in developing markets, as the Kazakh banks learned in mid-2007. The motivation for 
accessing foreign capital came from two sources. First, the banks could rapidly increase their 
ability to fund loans and other assets without relying on domestic deposits, which were more 
expensive (or so it appeared) and take longer to develop. Second, many borrowers were 
motivated to borrow in foreign currency (primarily the US dollar) because the interest rate was 
lower than the tenge equivalent and the risk of a significant appreciation in the value of the US 
dollar was seen as low (Table A4.2).

D.  The Present Situation 
 
78.  Recent problems have affected the sector.  At the beginning of 2009, three large 
Kazakh financial institutions—Bank Turan Alem (BTA), Alliance Bank, and Astana Finance—
defaulted and announced plans to restructure their foreign debt. The default of BTA Bank, the 
largest financial institution in the country, with a total asset market share of about 25%, raised 
concerns about banking system stability. 
 
79.  The banking sector in Kazakhstan has entered a new phase in recent weeks, 
contracting substantially in reaction to the cumulative effects of reduced access to credit 
and the diminution of asset values.2 As borrower ability to service debt continues to decline in 
a weakened economy, bank assets are increasingly reset by larger loss provisions that reflect 
loan repayment and collateral values in a declining real estate market. Provisions for loan loss 
have increased to over 15% from the low single digits less than a year ago. In June, two of the 
largest banks took provisions in excess of 57%, resulting in an average provision of 29% for the 
sector, effectively wiping out equity in the sector. The current status of equity capital stands at 
negative $1.5 billion for the sector, not taking into account potential reductions in liabilities and 
equity conversions pursuant to loan negotiations with global creditors. The authorities have 
taken control (both in ownership and management) of the three banks in default on foreign 
loans and effectively "ring-fenced" them from the sector (Figure A4.4). 
 
E.  Balance Sheets and Income Statements 
 
80.  Asset values continue to decline. Exacerbating the asset quality pressures are the 
higher cost of borrowing and the drop in residential real estate prices, which are down by more 
than 30% on average (and by 60% in some segments) since their peak in mid-2007 on lower 
sales  volumes.  Bank  lending  to  the  worst-affected  sectors—construction  and  real  estate—
represented 19% of total loans at the end of May 2008. Residential mortgages represented an 
additional 9%. Banks are further exposed to the drop in property prices, as more than 50% of 
their loans are collateralized with real estate. Complicating matters, the asset quality indicators 
that  Kazakh  banks  submit  may  misreport  actual  performance,  mainly  because  of  massive 
restructuring and rollover. Most loans are unseasoned and were extended during the upswing, 
and two thirds of loans have maturities greater than 5 years.

9.  Monitoring macroeconomic and financial sector performance. ADB will monitor and 
assess  macroeconomic  and  financial  sector  performance  during  the  program  period.  Key 
indicators to be monitored are the indicators presented in the Access Critieria 1 in Appendix 1. 
These indicators include 
(i)  GDP growth; 
(ii)  industrial output; 
(iii)  oil revenues and output; 
(iv)  fund flows in the National Fund of the Republic of Kazakhstan; 
(v)  fiscal position, public and external debts; 
(vi)  external balances; and 
(vii)  banking sector indicators such as capital adequacy ratios, loan loss provisions 
and nonperforming loan ratios.

provide  ADB,  on  a  quarterly  basis,  reports  on  macroeconomic  and  financial  sector 
developments. MLSP shall provide ADB, on a quarterly basis, reports on the employment, 
social and poverty situation, including indicators derived from the social assistance program, 
such as number of beneficiaries and disbursement for unemployment compensation, social 
insurance  and  targeted  social  assistance.  To  obtain  independent  assessments,  ADB  will 
regularly  hold  discussions  with  the  International  Monetary  Fund,  World  Bank  and  other 
development  partners  to  gather  information  on  the  macroeconomic  and  fiscal  situation  in 
Kazakhstan. ADB's assessments will also draw information from their staff reports and similar 
economic reviews. 
 
11.  Monitoring the implementation of anti-crisis measures. ADB will monitor and review 
the implementation and accomplishments of the anti-crisis measures, most especially on the 
aspects of spurring economic activity and creating jobs. ADB's monitoring will focus on the anti-
crisis measures that are financed from the budget. MEBP and MLSP shall provide ADB, on a 
quarterly  basis,  the  implementation  reports  on  each  component  of  the  ACP  and  the 
employment-generation program. These implementation reports will include: 
(i)  disbursements by key implementing entities of the ACP (Samruk–Kazyna and 
KazAgro) and the employment-generation program (various ministries and local 
governments); 
(ii)  disbursements and operation of the distressed asset fund; 
(iii)  lending activities of ACP-supported commercial banks; 
(iv)  lending activities of conduit banks or mortgage companies in real estate sector 
and SMEs; 
(v)  lending and loan guarantee activities by the Real Estate and Damu Funds; 
(vi)  number  and  amounts  received  by  beneficiaries  (construction  companies, 
mortgage borrowers and SMEs), including regional disaggregation; 
(vii)  completion rates of construction projects and their regional disggegregation; 
(viii)  sectoral distribution of beneficiary SMEs; 
(ix)  implementation  progress  in  selected  agro-industrial  infrastructure  and  energy 
projects; 
(x)  employment generation (including regional disaggregation) by the different anti-
crisis measures; and 
(xi)  retraining and internship program results.

A.   Background 
 
1.  Kazakhstan has consistently kept its public debt levels low and manageable. Between 
2006 and 2008, public and publicly guaranteed debt has been kept at an average of 6.4% of

the National Fund of the Republic of Kazakhstan (NFRK), which can be quickly mobilized to 
offset any debt shocks, net public debt is negative and averages at –12.8% of GDP. This clearly 
indicates that public debt is more than adequately covered and does not pose a risk to the 
economy. Moreover, the foreign exchange risk associated with public debt is quite low, as 80% 
of public debt is domestic. The ratio of public external debt to GDP averaged at 1.5% in 2006–
2008. For 2009, excluding the Kazakhstan Countercyclical Support Loan (KCSL), the ratio of 
public debt to GDP is expected to increase to 8.6%, and the ratio of public external debt to GDP 
is expected to increase to 1.5% of GDP.
